question:
Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: A 35-year-old male anesthesiologist presents to the occupational health clinic after a needlestick exposure while obtaining an arterial line in a patient with cirrhosis. In addition to a standard bloodborne pathogen laboratory panel sent for all needlestick exposures at his hospital, additional hepatitis panels are ordered upon the patient's request. The patient's results are shown below:

HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab: Negative/Negative
Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg): Negative
Hepatitis C antibody: Negative
Anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb): Positive
Anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM): Negative
Anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG): Positive

What is the most likely explanation of the results above?. If there are multiple answers, separate them with commas. In your explanation, point out what is correct and incorrect in the evidence.

content.source_1: In this occupational exposure setting involving a 35-year-old male anesthesiologist who sustained a needlestick while placing an arterial line in a patient with cirrhosis, the baseline serologic profile is informative: HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab is Negative/Negative; Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is Negative; Hepatitis C antibody is Negative; Anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) is Positive; Anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM) is Negative; and Anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG) is Positive. The absence of HBsAg excludes active hepatitis B infection, whereas the presence of HBc IgG, in the context of a negative HBc IgM, reliably indicates remote exposure rather than acute infection; coexistent HBsAb positivity is typical of convalescence or prior exposure with immune response. Taken together, these findings establish prior contact with hepatitis B virus without evidence of current viremia or acute seroconversion, consistent with Past Hepatitis B infection.
content.source_2: The post-exposure laboratory evaluation of this 35-year-old anesthesiologist shows HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab Negative/Negative, Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) Negative, Hepatitis C antibody Negative, Anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) Positive, Anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM) Negative, and Anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG) Positive. Serologic algorithms for hepatitis B interpret the combination of HBsAg negativity and HBc IgM negativity as excluding acute infection, while HBc IgG positivity signifies prior exposure. The concurrent presence of HBsAb indicates successful seroconversion and clearance of HBsAg, a pattern characteristic of resolved natural infection. In aggregate, the results depict a trajectory of past HBV exposure followed by antigen clearance and antibody-mediated recovery, best captured as Past hepatitis B infection with recovery.
content.source_3: Following a needlestick exposure, the anesthesiologist’s comprehensive assessment revealed HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab Negative/Negative, Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) Negative, Hepatitis C antibody Negative, Anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) Positive, Anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM) Negative, and Anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG) Positive. From a preventive health perspective, the key discriminator of protective status against hepatitis B is the presence of anti-HBs, which in this case is Positive, with no evidence of active infection (HBsAg Negative) or acute seroconversion (HBc IgM Negative). While HBc IgG positivity indicates remote exposure, the decisive finding for protective status is HBsAb positivity, which denotes effective immunologic protection against hepatitis B virus. Accordingly, the serologic profile supports the conclusion that the individual is Immunized against Hepatitis B.
content.source_4: The serologic profile obtained after a needlestick injury in a 35-year-old anesthesiologist—HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab Negative/Negative; Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) Negative; Hepatitis C antibody Negative; Anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) Positive; Anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM) Negative; Anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG) Positive—reflects the immunologic sequelae of resolved hepatitis B infection. HBc IgG positivity, in the absence of HBc IgM, indicates a past exposure with transition out of the acute phase, and the disappearance of HBsAg corroborates viral clearance. The presence of HBsAb signifies the establishment of protective humoral immunity, with neutralizing antibodies directed against the surface antigen and memory responses typical of convalescent immunologic consolidation after natural infection. Collectively, these results demonstrate Past hepatitis B infection, now immune.
content.source_5: In the context of occupational health surveillance following a percutaneous injury during arterial line placement in a cirrhotic source patient, the clinician’s baseline panel shows HIV 4th generation Ag/Ab Negative/Negative, Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) Negative, Hepatitis C antibody Negative, Anti-hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb) Positive, Anti-hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM) Negative, and Anti-hepatitis B core IgG antibody (HBc IgG) Positive. This constellation—HBsAg negativity excluding active HBV, HBc IgM negativity excluding acute infection, HBc IgG positivity indicating prior exposure, and HBsAb positivity indicating protective immunity—fits established post-exposure interpretive frameworks for hepatitis B, confirming resolved natural infection with durable serologic protection. The most accurate synthesis of these findings is Previous Hepatitis B infection, now immune.
